Reference: HTML <code>&lt;div&gt;</code> Challenge Blocks

Questions

  • How is a block defined with <div> tags?

Challenge block div

Formatting

HTML tags can be used inside of markdown as long as they are separated from markdown content by blank lines. Here, we use div tags (short for “Content division”) to create a our challenge and solution blocks.

Defining block type

The type of block is determined by the class flag. All div tags must have a closing tag that is formatted exactly like this: </div>. For example:

<div class='challenge'>

## Challenge

This is a *challenge*

</div>
<div class='callout'>

## Callout

This is a *callout*

</div>

Nesting blocks

To nest div tags, open a new div tag without closing the previous tag. If an opening tag does not have a matching closing (</div>) tag, then it is still open and your prose is still within that block.

<div class='challenge'>

## Challenge

This is a *challenge*

<div class='callout'>

## Callout

This is a *callout* inside a *challenge*

</div>

This is a *challenge* again

</div>

What to watch out for

Be careful with indentation because markdown recognizes anything indented with four spaces as code. Additionally, make sure you closing div tags start with a slash and that there is no space between the = sign:

<div class='callout'>

## Callout

Good

</div>

<div class = 'callout'>

## Callout

Bad (space between `=`)

</div>

    <div class='callout'>

    ## Callout
    
    Bad (will be processed as a code block)
    
    </div>
    
<div class='callout'>
## Callout

Bad (no space between tags and markdown)
</div>

Example

This shows an example of a solution div tag nested inside of a challenge div tag.

Example of div markdown specifying a challenge and solution in python

Challenge

Use the + operator to concatenate the strings “hello” and “there” in python

Solution

"hello " + "there"
"hello there"
